lexUnit.name: disdain.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: consider or reject with the feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect

sentence.text: I blush to admit it , but those of us who were born into the trade tend to disdain these crossovers as an inferior breed .
She had disdained the smaller waves in the shelter of the islands , but now she seemed to tremble as her hull soaked up the ponderous force of the ocean .
She disdains his odious advances , and makes an inspiring speech on the glorious revolutionary future .
Genius , as it disdains all assistance , so it defies all obstacles .
As he sat on the mud floor of his cell , disdaining the bed , he said that he would do exactly the same again .
Now Lady De Marr staggers into the front door , saluted by the guard , the askari , disdaining the proffered help of the major , who wears a fez and a sash .

He wanted all writers to live obscurely in the provinces , ignore the natural affections of the heart , disdain reputation , and spend solitary , back-breaking hours reading obscure texts by the light of a tiring candle .
But such simple fare he knew full well would be disdained .
Yet Urquhart had felt omnipotent , God-like , viewing His Kingdom from on high , disdaining the logic and fears which beset the ordinary mortals around him .
If you are elected to college committees , do not disdain what appears to be a minor representation .
After all , it is everyone 's children who stand to suffer from theories which , to take only one example , disdain the teaching of history in factual terms .
Their most outrageous step toward re-regulation is rigging the stockmarket , which officials once disdained as a mucky casino .
Choreographers have never disdained to use popular music for their everincreasing audiences and they realise that they should reflect popular taste .
He was prepared to buy off political pressure , as over workplace nurseries , in a way Mr Lawson would surely have disdained .
Even the casual Aranyos did not disdain to make the sign .
Nor , said Thomas Gisborne in 1795 , must he himself disdain to borrow money at the appropriate moment if he is not to put his credit to real and serious hazard .
Was it sheer bravado on Obispal 's part that he disdained to fire explosive bolts at that creature which itself could not manipulate a gun ?
